 Rewriting actually bothers me less than omitting huge chunks of what, for me, makes any story interesting; character development, which is usually conveyed through dialogue. All the HP films so far just seem incredibly rushed, you barely have time to take in a new plot development before it's done with, which is why I think they should have made OotP longer, and hopefully will do will the next two films.
 
 LotR works because Jackson is an awesome director and although there was a lot of monkeying around with details, the overall 'feel' of the story, I felt, was beautifully captured by the films. Maybe it's because of the 'mythological' feel of the story that it doesn't matter so much for me if changes are made, as long as they don't screw up the film as a whole. The films of LotR are essentially Jackson's interpretation of the story, and they work as a stand-alone whole, even if that whole is different to the books.
 
 The HP films, on the other hand, concentrate too much on just creating something that fans of the books can go and watch for pleasure, rather than being stand-alone works of art. I think that if you hadn't read the books, the HP films would be largely a jumbled, confused mess, and you would be left with a lot of unanswered questions. However there are millions of people who have seen LotR without reading the books and they love it because it makes sense as a stand-alone work.
 
 Essentially, I'm less interested in just seeing a visual representation of a story that I love, than I am in seeing something that can be enjoyed for its own sake. A film of a book can never be the book, so if details have to be mixed and matched, so be it, just don't rush through it leaving out loads of the depth and richness of the story.
